title: Service instance management
content:
A subscription originates with a subscription request, initiated by the subscriber (end user)  in the Service Portal. After a subscription request is approved, a service instance is created. A service instance is also created when performing a test deployment from the DEPLOYMENTS tab for a service design. 

The test deployments and subscriptions listed in the DEPLOYMENTS tab contain a link to launch the service instance detail page of Deployment Operations. You can view the tree of all the components that are part of the deployed instance.

To view the summary and details of service instances, go to Run > Deployment Operations > Instance Management. The service instances are listed by Instances, Design, or Users. By default, the instances are listed By Instance. 

Select the By Design option to view the list of instances deployed for a design. The Designs panel will display the name and version of the design. You can use the Search box to search for designs based on the design name or version. Select a design to view the service instances deployed for it.

Select the By Users option to view the instances owned by a user. The Users panel will display the name and email id of a user. You can use the Search box to search for users based on username. Search by email address isn't supported. Select a user to view the service instances owned by the user. 

Use the search box available at the top of the Instance Management page to search for an instance by its name. You can also search using multiple keywords.

Summary

The summary provides the following charts:

  • The number of Active, In Progress, Paused, Failed, and Canceled instances.
  • Provider type distribution summary of the instances.

Service Instances

Select the option By Instance to view the list of service instances and the following details.

Item Description
Name

Displays the name of the instance.
Design Displays the name of the design.
State

Displays the state of the instance.

The possible states of a service instance are as below:

  Active - The instance is active.

  Paused (On Action Error) - The instance is paused due to an error executing an action. More information about the lifecycle stage in which the instance paused is available in a tooltip and on the instance detail page.

  Paused (On Action Success)- The instance is paused due to the configuration of an action indicating to pause after successful completion. More information about the lifecycle stage in which the instance paused is available in a tooltip and on the instance detail page.

   In Progress - The instance is in the process of being provisioned, modified, or canceled.

  Canceled - The instance is canceled.

  Failed - The instance had a failure, either during provisioning, modification, cancellation, or when running a user operation.  More information about the failure is available in a tooltip and on the instance detail page.  Note that the corresponding subscription for an instance that's Failed may still be Active if the failure occurred during modification or when running a user operation.

Use the filter option to list the instances as per the state.
Owner

Displays the user that requested the subscription.
Created Displays the date and time of the instance creation.
Type Displays the type of the instance. For example, Subscription or Test Deployment.
Action Displays the Canel Subscription action that can be executed only on the Subscription instance. This field is blank for Test deployment instances. You can cancel the subscription only if the instance is in Active, Paused, or Failed state.

Service Instance details

Select the service instance to view more details of the instance.  The state displayed at the top right of the instance detail page is more descriptive than the state shown in the instances table. The possible states are shown below.

States displayed in Instances table States displayed on instance detail page and description
Active Active - The service instance is active.
In Progress

Provisioning - The service instance is being provisioned.
Modifying - The service instance is being modified.
Canceling - The service instance is being canceled.
Paused

Provisioning Paused (On Action Error) - The service instance is paused due to an error that occurred during provisioning. To resume or fail the provisioning, follow the steps documented in the section Resume or fail an instance paused during provisioning due to an error in an action.
Modification Paused (On Action Error) - The service instance is paused due to an error that occurred during modification. To resume, reset, or fail the modification, follow the steps documented in the section Resume, reset, or fail an instance paused during modification due to an error in an action.
Cancellation Paused (On Action Error) - The service instance is paused due to an error that occurred during cancellation. To resume the cancellation, follow the steps documented in the section Resume an instance paused during cancellation due to an error in an action.

Provisioning Paused (On Action Success) - The instance is paused during provisioning due to the configuration of an action indicating to pause after successful completion. To resume or fail the provisioning, follow the steps documented in the section Resume or fail an instance paused during provisioning on successful completion of an action.
Modification Paused (On Action Success) - The instance is paused during modification due to the configuration of an action indicating to pause after successful completion. To resume, reset, or fail the modification, follow the steps documented in the section Resume, reset, or fail an instance paused during modification on successful completion of an action.
Cancellation Paused (On Action Success) -The instance is paused during cancellation due to the configuration of an action indicating to pause after successful completion.  To resume the cancellation, follow the steps documented in the section Resume an instance paused during cancellation on successful completion of an action.
Canceled Canceled - The service instance is canceled.
Failed

Modification Failed (No More Modifications Are Allowed) - The service instance modification has failed and no more modifications are allowed.

Modification Failed (Additional Modifications Are Allowed) - The service instance modification has failed but additional modifications are allowed.

User Operation Failed - The User Operation has failed. For more information on how to add user operations to a service design, see User operations for service design.

Provisioning Failed - The service instance provisioning has failed.
Cancellation Failed - The service instance cancellation has failed.

Select the below options to see more service instance details.

Component details

Select the Components option on the instance detail page to view the tree of all the components that are part of the deployed instance. The tree items are collapsible. You can search for a component using the search box.

Field Description
Component Name Name of the component
State

This field indicates the state of the component for the service instance lifecycle.

The possible states are:

  • Deploying
  • Modifying
  • Deployed
  • Undeployed
  • Undeploying
  • Paused
  • Unknown
  • Failed

Select the component to open a side panel that will display the properties, user operations, and events associated with the component. 

In the PROPERTIES tab, you can check Hide Empty Properties to hide the properties that don't contain any values. The properties tab also displays any properties that exist on resource offerings associated with the service component. 

The USER OPERATIONS tab displays the user operations linked to the service design of the instance. You will see the user operations listed either under the component or under the resource offerings or under both based on how you have configured them. As an Operations Manager with the DND_OPERATIONS_GATEWAY_TENANT_ADMIN permission, you will be able to see the list of user operations for the instances associated with subscriptions and also test deployments under the USER OPERATIONS tab and will be able to execute them from the instance management page.

Note: As a service portal user, for service instances associated with subscriptions from the Service Portal, you will be able to see the list of user operations for the instance under the USER OPERATIONS tab but you will not be able to execute them from the instance management page. These user operations can be run only from the Service Portal. You will see a banner "User operations can only be run from the Service Portal for instances associated with subscriptions." for such instances in the user operations tab.

You will not be able to execute the listed user operations, if the service instance is in the following states:

  • Cancelled
  • Modifiying (Once the state changes to active, you can execute the user operation.)

Once you click on a user operation, a dialog box will list all the component properties required to execute the user operation if you have configured the properties as Prompt User. You will need to provide the inputs for the mandatory properties. This tab only supports string inputs. You need to enter the list, integer, and Boolean properties manually as text. You need to satisfy input validation to enable the EXECUTE button. Semantic validation happens when you click the EXECUTE button. If there are any errors while providing inputs, an error icon will appear near that field. On hover, you will see the description of the error. After you resolve the validation errors, you can execute the user operation.

The EVENTS tab of the side panel displays the events associated with the component. The event tab also contains a link to the run of the flow in OO, which can be used to troubleshoot any failures that occur during the execution of the flow. For more information on OO flows and troubleshooting, see Test and troubleshooting a flow run.

Provider details

Select the Providers option on the instance detail page to view which resource providers were used for provisioning or interacting with different cloud resources for a given service instance.

Field Description
Type The resource provider type.
Name The resource provider display name.
User The user configured for the resource provider. 
Access Point The access point (URI) of the resource provider

Event details

Select the Events option on the instance detail page to view the events that have been run for the instance. Events correlate to actions defined in the service design, though some events, such as Fulfillment Engine Events, are system generated.

Field Description
Event Time Date and time when the event was run.
Lifecycle Stage and Phase The lifecycle stage and phase in which the action ran.  For more information on lifecycle stages and phases, see Lifecycle actions for service design.
Action The display name of the action.
Source The source of the action in the design.  For an action defined directly on a service component in a design, the source of the event will be the display name of the service component in a design.  For an action defined on a resource offering, the source of the event will be the display name of the resource offering.  Provider selection actions will have a source value that includes both the resource offering and service component display names.
State

This field displays the state of the event. Detailed information about the event can be seen in the tooltip.

Completed - The event has been successfully executed.

Transition Paused on Error - An action error has caused the instance to pause. 

Transition Paused on Success - The instance is paused as requested after the successful completion of an action.

Transition Resumed - An operator has resumed a paused service instance.

Transition Canceled - An operator has chosen to fail a service instance that was paused during provisioning.

Transition Aborted - An operator has chosen to reset or fail a service instance that was paused during modification.

Failed - The event has failed during execution. 

For actions that correspond to Operations Orchestration (OO) flows, the State field contains a link to the run of the flow in OO.  You can use this link to help troubleshoot any errors that occurred during the execution of the flow. For more information on OO flows and troubleshooting, see Test and troubleshooting a flow run.

Log details

Select the Logs option on the instance detail page to view the logs related to a service instance.

Log messages are created for key events that occur during the service instance lifecycle.  These include, for example:

  • The initial creation of the instance.
  • The execution of OO flows or internal actions.
  • An instance pausing or resuming.
  • An instance reaching a stable state such as Active or Failed.

The Logs view complements the Events view and includes additional information, such as the inputs and outputs of each flow execution, that are otherwise only visible by viewing a flow execution in OO.

The Logs view automatically scrolls to the bottom for an in-progress instance, showing new log records as they occur.

Logs can be downloaded as a ZIP archive by clicking the Download icon.

Logs are automatically deleted when an instance is canceled.

Resume, reset, or fail the service instance paused due to an error in an action

Resume or fail an instance paused during provisioning due to an error in an action

For a service instance paused during provisioning, an operator, on the instance detail page, can either resume or fail provisioning.

  • Resume Provisioning

    Select this option to resume provisioning, either by re-running or skipping the actions that had failed.

    The decision of whether to re-run or skip failed actions should be made by the operator after assessing the cause of the error.  Most action errors will be the result of a failure while running an Operations Orchestration flow.  If the flow is written in a re-runnable fashion, an operator may wish to re-run the failed action after correcting the cause of the failure.  In other cases, an operator may wish to manually perform the activity the flow failed to perform or to otherwise ignore that activity, and to then skip the action that had failed when resuming provisioning.

    After resuming provisioning, the instance will initially return to a Provisioning state and proceed with the remaining provisioning actions configured in the design in an attempt to bring the instance to an Active state.  If another action error occurs after resuming provisioning, the instance will pause again.

  • Fail Provisioning 

    Select this option to fail the provisioning of the instance if the instance can't be safely resumed or is no longer required. On Failure actions configured in the service design will be run. The service instance state will become Provisioning Failed, and a subscriber will see a subscription status of Terminated. For more information on how to add On Failure actions, see Lifecycle actions for service design.

Resume, reset, or fail an instance paused during modification due to an error in an action

For a service instance paused during subscription modification, a banner will be displayed at the bottom with options to resume, reset, or fail the modification. 

  • Resume modification

    Select this option to resume modification, either by re-running or skipping the actions that had failed.

    The decision of whether to re-run or skip failed actions should be made by the operator after assessing the cause of the error.  Most action errors will be the result of a failure while running an Operations Orchestration flow.  If the flow is written in a re-runnable fashion, an operator may wish to re-run the failed action after correcting the cause of the failure.  In other cases, an operator may wish to manually perform the activity the flow failed to perform or to otherwise ignore that activity, and to then skip the action that had failed when resuming provisioning.

    After resuming modification, the instance will initially return to a Modifying state and proceed with the remaining modification actions configured in the design in an attempt to bring the instance to an Active state.  If another action error occurs after resuming modification, the instance will pause again.

  • Reset modification

    Select this option to reset modification. Resetting the modification will restore the configuration options and property selections to the values that they were before modification. You will be able to perform further modifications to the subscription if required.

    Note: As part of resetting an option property value, any service instance property that had a binding configured from this option property is also reset to the value it held prior to modification.  This may result in the service instance property value differing from the provisioned state of the resource associated with the service instance.  In such cases, an operator will need to manually adjust the actual resource state (for example, the configuration of a provisioned VM) to match the reset property values.
  • Fail modification

    Select this option to fail the modification if the modification can't be safely resumed or reset. On Failure actions configured in the service design will be run. The subscription will remain active but no further modification of the subscription will be allowed. In the Service Portal the actions dropdown will not have the option to modify the subscription. For more information on how to add On Failure actions, see Lifecycle actions for service design.

Note: There is a short delay after a Reset Modification or Fail Modification before the Service Portal is updated to reflect that change.  In particular, the Actions dropdown in the Service Portal may take a minute to reappear.

Resume an instance paused during cancellation due to an error in an action

For a service instance paused during cancellation, an operator, on the instance detail page, can resume cancellation.

  • Resume Cancellation

    Select this option to resume cancellation, either by re-running or skipping the actions that had failed.

    The decision whether to re-run or skip failed actions should be made by the operator after assessing the cause of the error.  Most action errors will be the result of a failure while running an Operations Orchestration flow.  If the flow is written in a re-runnable fashion, an operator may wish to re-run the failed action after correcting the cause of the failure.  In other cases, an operator may wish to manually perform the activity the flow failed to perform, or to otherwise ignore that activity, and to then skip the action that had failed when resuming cancellation.

    After resuming cancellation, the instance will initially return to a Canceling state and proceed with the remaining de-provisioning actions configured in the design in an attempt to bring the instance to a Canceled state.  If another action failure occurs after resuming cancellation, the instance will pause again.

Resume, reset, or fail the service instance paused on successful completion of an action

Resume or fail an instance paused during provisioning on successful completion of an action

For a service instance paused during provisioning, an operator, on the instance detail page, can either resume or fail provisioning.

  • Resume Provisioning

    Select this option to resume provisioning.

    After resuming provisioning, the instance will initially return to a Provisioning state and proceed with the remaining provisioning actions configured in the design in an attempt to bring the instance to an Active state. 

  • Fail Provisioning 

    Select this option to fail the provisioning of the instance if the instance can't be safely resumed or is no longer required. The service instance state will become Provisioning Failed, and a subscriber will see a subscription status of Terminated. 

Resume, reset or fail an instance paused during modification on successful completion of an action

For a service instance paused during subscription modification, a banner will be displayed at the bottom with options to resume, reset, or fail the modification. 

  • Resume modification

    Select this option to resume modification.

    After resuming modification, the instance will initially return to a Modifying state and proceed with the remaining modification actions configured in the design in an attempt to bring the instance to an Active state.  

  • Reset modification

    Select this option to reset modification. Resetting the modification will restore the configuration options and property selections to the values that they were before modification. You will be able to perform further modifications to the subscription if required.

    Note: As part of resetting an option property value, any service instance property that had a binding configured from this option property is also reset to the value it held prior to modification.  This may result in the service instance property value differing from the provisioned state of the resource associated with the service instance.  In such cases, an operator will need to manually adjust the actual resource state (for example, the configuration of a provisioned VM) to match the reset property values.
  • Fail modification

    Select this option to fail the modification if the modification can't be safely resumed or reset. The subscription will remain active but no further modification of the subscription will be allowed. In the Service Portal the actions dropdown will not have the option to modify the subscription. 

Note: There is a short delay after a Reset Modification or Fail Modification before the Service Portal is updated to reflect that change.  In particular, the Actions dropdown in the Service Portal may take a minute to reappear.

Resume an instance paused during cancellation on successful completion of an action

For a service instance paused during cancellation, an operator, on the instance detail page, can resume cancellation.

  • Resume Cancellation

    Select this option to resume cancellation.

    After resuming cancellation, the instance will initially return to a Canceling state and proceed with the remaining de-provisioning actions configured in the design in an attempt to bring the instance to a Canceled state.  

Resume a paused service instance using an API

An instance that is paused after successful completion of an action can be resumed in the Deployment Operations UI or by invoking an API.
To resume the paused instance by invoking an API, issue an HTTP POST call, with an empty body, to the endpoint https://<hostname>/<tenantId>/dnd/api/service/instance/<instanceId>/resume.

Set the following headers in the HTTP call

Accept - application/json

Authorization - <Base64EncodedUserNameAndPassword>

To create the <Base64EncodedUserNameAndPassword> value, use a Base64 encoder to encode <username>:<password> (e.g. dndAdminUser:myPassword) for a user with permissions to resume service instances (such as the tenant admin user created for DND).

To get the <instanceId>, go to Deployment Operations and select the service instance that you would like to resume. The browser URL will be in the format https://<hostname>/dnd-operations-gateway/#/instance/<instanceId>/components. The <instanceId> will be the value that immediately follows /instance/ in the URL.

Example: If the service instance URL is https://myHost.myLab.net/dnd-operations-gateway/#/instance/2c90849e787b42d901787b790e4a6638/components, the <instanceId> will be 2c90849e787b42d901787b790e4a6638.

If the instance was able to be resumed successfully, a 200 HTTP response and empty JSON body will be returned.
